data.text:
As an author, there’s nothing more rewarding than having your work recognised. Winning a major book award and being called an “award-winning author” can really boost your career. In the ever-changing world of books, awards are a huge deal. They highlight amazing talent, celebrate fantastic stories, and give deserving authors the attention they’ve been working so hard for. There are many literary awards out there, but a few are super prestigious and can make a real difference in an author’s life. These awards offer not just financial rewards, but also the recognition and respect every author dreams of.

{Trying to brush up your humour in writing. Our post Writing A Funny Story may be of help.}

What are Literary Awards?

A literary award is all about celebrating great storytelling. They validate authors, push them into the limelight, and help them connect with a wider audience. They can also be financial lifelines, allowing writers to focus on their craft without worrying about money. Plus, winning an award means your name gets written into literary history with other famous writers.

Sure, some people might argue that these awards can be biased or too commercial, but let’s be honest: their impact is undeniable. They prove that words have the power to move hearts and minds.

What is Sahitya Akademi Awards?

Sahitya Akademi Awards is one of India’s most prestigious literary honours. The award is given out by the Sahitya Akademi, an independent body which is part of the Ministry of Culture, every year to honour outstanding authors. These awards recognise exceptional books written in various Indian languages.

Where it all started?

Sahitya Akademi is dedicated to promoting literature in various Indian languages. It was founded by the government on March 12, 1954. It is supported by the Ministry of Culture, though it operates independently.

Their main office is in New Delhi, with regional offices in Kolkata, Bangalore, and Mumbai. The Akademi is also known for publishing books and magazines that focus on literary criticism, research, and other writings about Indian literature. What makes the Sahitya Akademi special? It’s the only institution that promotes and supports literature in 24 Indian languages, including English.

The Prize

The Sahitya Akademi Award is a highly prestigious literary honour in India. Here’s what winners of this award usually receive:

Prize Money: The prize money has increased significantly over the years. It started at Rs. 5,000 when the awards first started. It increased to Rs. 10,000 in 1983, Rs. 25,000 in 1988, Rs. 40,000 in 2001, and Rs. 50,000 in 2003. Since 2009, the prize has been Rs. 1,00,000. The first awards were presented in 1955, and it has remained a cherished tradition ever since.

Plaque: Along with the money, winners receive a bronze plaque. It was designed by the Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray. This plaque is a special symbol of their literary achievement and recognition by the Sahitya Akademi.

Citation: Winners also get a citation. This is a formal statement that highlights their contribution to literature and explains why their specific work was chosen.

Public Recognition: Beyond the prize and plaque, the award gives authors significant public recognition and prestige.

Selection Process

The selection process for the Sahitya Akademi Award is detailed and involves several steps to ensure that the most deserving literary works are recognized. Here is a breakdown of the selection process:

Nominations:

The nominations are typically for the books published in the previous five years in any of the 24 recognised Indian languages.

Authors cannot nominate their own works.

Expert evaluation:

Two experts are chosen for each of the 24 recognised Indian languages.

These experts prepare a ground list of notable books published in their respective languages.

Advisory Board Recommendations:

Members of the language advisory boards receive the ground list created by the experts.

Based on this ground list, each advisory board member compiles and forwards their own list of recommended books.

Preliminary Panel Review:

A Preliminary Panel is formed for each language, consisting of 10 scholars who are well-versed in that language.

The Preliminary Panel reviews the recommendations provided by the advisory board members.

The Panel’s role is to further evaluate and refine the list of recommended books.

Jury Selection:

The refined list of recommendations from the Preliminary Panel is reviewed by a 3-member jury.

The jury, consisting of distinguished literary figures, reviews these recommendations in detail.

From the list, the jury selects the final winner for the Sahitya Akademi Award in that language.

Announcement and Awarding:

The Sahitya Akademi formally announces the winners.

This meticulous and thorough process ensures that the most deserving books are celebrated.

So far, 1239 books have been awarded the Sahitya Akademi Award across all 24 languages, highlighting the outstanding quality of Indian literature.

Eligibility Criteria

To be eligible for the award, a book must be an exceptional contribution to its language and literature. Here’s what qualifies and what doesn’t:

The author must be an Indian citizen.

The book must have been published within the previous five years from the year of the award consideration.

The award covers various literary genres, including novels, short stories, plays, poetry, biographies, autobiographies, travelogues, and critical studies.

The book must not be:

A translation.

An anthology by multiple authors.

An abridgement, compilation, or annotation.

A treatise or research work prepared for a degree or exam.

A work by an author who has previously won a Sahitya Akademi Award (except for the Translation Prize, Bal Sahitya Puraskar, or Yuva Puraskar).

A work by a recipient of Bhasha Samman.

A work by a fellow of Sahitya Akademi.

A work by an author who is a current member of the Executive Board of the Akademi.

Collections of previously published works or revised editions are generally not eligible. However, if at least 75% of the collection is newly published, it can still be considered.

An incomplete work can be eligible if the part that is published is complete in itself.

Posthumous works are eligible if the author died within the last five years before the award year. For instance, an author who died before 2018 would not be eligible for the 2024 award.

A book will be disqualified if the author is found to be canvassing for the award.

Authors and publishers cannot submit books directly for the award.

Other Sahitya Akademi Awards

Sahitya Akademi Bal Sahitya Puraskar

This award is for authors who have made significant contributions to children’s literature.

It focuses on those works that have captured the hearts and minds of young readers.

Sahitya Akademi Yuva Puraskar

This award is aimed at celebrating young authors who are under the age of 35.

It is about encouraging fresh voices in literature and encouraging the growth and development of young writers.

Facts about Sahitya Akademi Award

Every year, on January 26, Republic Day, the President of India gives out the awards at a special ceremony at Rashtrapati Bhawan in New Delhi.

R.K. Narayana was the first to win the Sahitya Akademi Award for English in 1960 for his novel “The Guide”.

The first woman to win the Sahitya Akademi Award was Amrita Pritam, a renowned Punjabi writer, who received the award in 1956 for her collection of poetry titled “Sunehe”.

The plaque awarded by the Sahitya Akademi was designed by the renowned Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray.

During the Indo-Pakistan War of 1965, they replaced the plaque with a national savings bond as a symbol of support.

Makhanlal Chaturvedi was the first Hindi writer to win the award in 1955 for his poetry collection “Him Tarangini”.

Its headquarters in New Delhi serves as a hub for literary events, seminars, and workshops to promote literary awareness and foster cultural dialogue.

The Sahitya Akademi Award is the second-highest literary honour after the Sahitya Akademi Fellowship.

The Sahitya Akademi also gives out other awards like the Bhasha Samman Puraskar, Translation Prize, and Bal Sahitya Puraskar.

The Translation Prize from the Sahitya Akademi honours translators for their pivotal role in bringing different languages and cultures together through literature.

Renowned authors like Rabindranath Tagore, Mulk Raj Anand, and Mahasweta Devi are among the recipients of the Sahitya Akademi Award.

THWR Faculty who have clinched the award

Jerry Pinto, a renowned Indian author and journalist, received the Sahitya Akademi Award for his novel “Em and the Big Hoom”. The novel revolves around the life of a young boy growing up in Mumbai with his family. The story particularly focuses on his relationship with his mother, referred to as Em, who suffers from bipolar disorder. It explores topics like mental health, family connections, and love amidst challenges. The novel beautifully portrays the emotional journeys of the characters dealing with mental illness, earning praise from both readers and critics.

Wrapping up

The Sahitya Akademi Award is a special honour for writers who create stories that touch our hearts and minds. The award’s goal is to appreciate and inspire great writing in India, recognizing the best works while also keeping an eye on new and exciting developments in literature. These awards celebrate diverse voices and highlight the power of storytelling to inspire and connect us all.
